intro: Cleome paradoxa, commonly known as the "spider flower," is a flowering plant native to the southern United States and Mexico. It is characterized by its distinctive, spindly stems and clusters of small, yellowish-white flowers that resemble spiders, hence its common name. The plant typically grows in full sun to partial shade and thrives in well-drained soils. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. Cleome paradoxa is often cultivated as an ornamental plant for its unique appearance and ability to attract pollinators.
